description.narrative: NVSL-FADDL, was invited to teach a foreign animal diseases training course entitled Quarantinable Diseases, held in Piura, Peru. This course, sponsored by the SENASA branch of the Peruvian Ministry of Agriculture, provided training to Animal Quarantine workers for the government of Peru. Topics covered included FMD, Vesicular Stomatitis Virus, Swine Vesicular Disease, CSF and ASF.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

description.narrative: Due to the number of trainees, this was part two of a two part training program on Cold Treatment. Officials from Peru SENASA were trained on how to initiate cold treatments for imports into the US. The Chilean Preclearance Program provided the training and was funded by SENASA-Peru.

title.narrative: International Symposium of Avian Influenza, Lima Peru, June 22, 2017

description.narrative: General Objective: to update the knowledge of the professionals of the various Official Services of the Region, producers and public in general, on the progress, challenges and perspectives in the prevention, control and elimination of outbreaks of this disease.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: APHIS training of Agriculture Inspectors with Peru's Ministry of Agriculture

description.narrative: Peru is the second largest producer of asparagus and largest exporter of fresh asparagus with about 70% of total exports going the United States. In cooperation with Argentinas National Food Safety and Quality Service (SENASA), APHIS completed a training workshop for plant health inspectors on the protocol for collecting and shipping insects diagnostic testing. The goal of the workshop was to sample and identify live insects found on Peruvian asparagus bound for the U.S. market, which will help allow Peruvian producers to continue exporting this product to the United States.

description.narrative: The Food for Progress Program provides for the donation of U.S. agricultural commodities to developing countries and emerging democracies that are committed to introducing or expanding free enterprise in their agricultural economies. The program has two primary strategic objectives: (1) increase agricultural productivity and (2) expand trade of agricultural products.

title.narrative: Scientific Cooperation Research Program - Quantifying Ecosystem Services On Silvo-Pastoral Systems (SPS) In The Peruvian Amazon To Improve Small Holder Productivity

description.narrative: The Scientific Cooperation Research Program supports joint research, extension, and education projects lasting up to two years among domestic and international agricultural professionals. These projects address issues including agricultural trade and market access, animal and plant health, biotechnology, food safety and security, and sustainable natural resource management.
